title: Data Collection Best Practices for AI-Powered Maintenance
content:
Our maintenance data collection is inconsistent across different facilities, making it difficult to implement AI effectively. Need guidance on:

1. Standardizing data collection methods
2. Determining optimal sampling frequencies
3. Handling missing/incomplete data
4. Data quality validation processes
5. Storage and retention policies

What practices have worked well in your organizations?

replies.content:
We standardized our data collection across 12 sites. Key steps:

1. Created unified data dictionary
2. Implemented automated validation rules
3. Set up real-time quality monitoring
4. Established data governance team

Biggest impact came from involving maintenance technicians in the process - they helped identify what data was actually useful vs. theoretical requirements.
@Michael - How did you handle resistance from technicians? We're struggling with compliance in manual data entry, especially during busy periods.

Lisa, we solved this by:

1. Mobile data entry apps
2. Voice-to-text for quick notes
3. Automated data capture where possible
4. Weekly review meetings

Key was showing techs how better data directly improved their work - faster diagnosis, fewer repeat issues, more planned vs. reactive work.

For sampling frequencies, we use this framework:

1. Critical equipment: 5-minute intervals
2. High-impact: 15-minute intervals
3. Standard: Hourly
4. Low-priority: Daily

Storage policy: Raw data for 3 months, aggregated data for 5 years. Using time-series DB for efficiency.

seo.description: Expert discussion on best practices for collecting and managing maintenance data for AI-powered systems, including standardization, quality control, and practical implementation strategies.
